IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To provide safe emergency shelter and intervention services for minors in Riverside County with our Supportive Housing and Transitional Housing Programs which provide services and housing to youths 11-21.
IRS990.MissionDesc: To provide safe emergency shelter and intervention services for minors in Riverside County with our Supportive Housing and Transitional Housing Programs which provide services and housing to youths 11-21.
IRS990.Desc: Emergency SheltersLocated in Riverside and Thousand Palms, these facilities accept males and females, ages 12 - 17, every hour of every day of the year. They are the only shelters in Riverside County providing twenty-four hour a day services to runaway, throwaway and homeless youth. Immediate interventions include three weeks of emergency shelter, food, clothing, daily counseling, family reunification when possible, and ongoing grade level education. The daily counseling services, as well as family sessions assist the teens and their families in addressing individual and family issues in a positive way that is helpful for all family members. A 24-hour toll free crisis line is also available for youth in crisis.Supportive Housing and Transitional Housing ProgramsLocated in Riverside (Main Street) and Thousand Palms (Harrison House), these apartment settings provide on-going services for up to eighteen months for older youth ages 18 - 24 who are aging out of foster care or who are homeless. Services include life skills, financial education, employment assistance, continuing education, and mental health counseling. The program goal is to move the youth from homelessness to permanent housing and self-sufficiency.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule L, Part V Supplemental Information
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Related party payables at June 30, 2017 include $ 200,000 to Amy S. Harrison, Board president, for advances made to assist with payoff of a construction loan. Interest is accumulated monthly at 7% and the loan is payable on demand. In December 2017, this Board member allowed Operation SafeHouse, Inc. (OSH) to be forgiven of $100,000 which consisted of $60,452 of outstanding obligation and forgiveness of accreud interest of $39,548. At June 30, 2018, the balance of this related party payable was $139,548.In August 2010, Amy S. Harrison, board president, negotiated the purchase of a $2,332,250 outstanding building loan with the bank, which then released OSH of any further obligation to the bank, in exchange for a $1.5 million loan payable to her. The loan was payable interest only with a rate of 5.5% and monthly interest payments of $ 4,590, with principal due on demand. As of June 30, 2018 the balance of this loan was $ 672,095. The combined outstanding related party payables at June 30, 2018 amounted to $ 811,643. These loans have been classified as long-term liabilities on the statement of financial position even though they are payable on demand. Management has made the determination that since they have a good relationship with the Board member and has determined repayment is not expected in the near future. OSH had accumulated interest related to these loans of approximately $25,000 for the year ended June 30, 2018 and these amounts are included in accounts payable. In addition to the loans described above the board Member also leases the Organization property for use as two of the Organization's group homes. The total monthly amount due under these leases were $4,200, however one lease was terminated in March 2018 and the other was terminated in June 2018. As of June 30, 2018, lease payments made to this board member amounted to $37,800.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 3: Ceased Conducting or Significant Changes To Services
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Operation Safehouse, Inc. closed group home in January 2018

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b: Form 990 Review Process
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The return is reviewed by Kathy Mc Adara, executive director, and draft copies of the form 990 are presented to the Board of Directors for their approval prior to filing the completed return.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: An annual questionnaire is provided to the Board of Directors to disclose any conflicts of interest.
